question: Can the {level} {race} {class} use advantage on their Deception check because the lie that {Mollymauk} is {Lucien Nonagon} has some truth to it?
answer: The GM can allow the {level} {race} {class} to have advantage on the Deception check.
rules: Section > Using Ability Scores > Ability Checks
Part I > MATT: Make a deception check both of you.
Part I > TALIESIN: Technically advantage because it's kind of the truth?
rules_explanation: Advantage on an ability check is determined by circumstances at the GM's discretion.

question: If {Fjord} is telling the truth, does {Taliesin} still have to roll a deception check?
answer: The {level} {race} {class} does not have to make a Deception check if they are not lying.
rules: Part II > LIAM: I'm going to-- Insight check.
Section > Using Ability Scores > Ability Checks
Part II > MATT: You don't have to roll deception if you're not lying.
rules_explanation: A Deception check is only necessary if the character is trying to deceive someone, and thus lying.

question: As per the Zone of Truth spell, does the {level} {race} {class} have to be entirely honest?
answer: The spell description for Zone of Truth will describe how the spell forces creatures under its effect to speak truthfully.
rules: Part II > SAM: Jester would like to cast Zone of Truth.
Part II > LIAM: Well, you can say whatever you want, but whatever you say has to be true. That's how it works.
rules_explanation: The spell itself will describe the effects of the spell.

question: If the {level} {race} {class} did switch hands, what kind of check would that be?
answer: A Sleight of Hand check contested by the target's Perception.
rules: Part I > MATT: Make a sleight of hand check versus his perception.
Section > Using Ability Scores > Ability Checks > Contests
rules_explanation: Sleight of Hand is used to perform manual trickery, and Perception is used to notice things.
